title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that have cooperative agreements with a State or submit arrangements for the provision of child welfare services. Programs operated by Indian tribal organizations are covered under SEC. 479B. Indian tribes operating under this part must follow the same rules as states, with modifications allowed for tribal plans to identify service areas and approve foster homes based on tribal standards ensuring child safety and accountability. The Federal medical assistance percentage applicable to an Indian tribe is based on the tribe's per capita income calculated from its service population defined in its plan. The Secretary will determine proportions to be paid to Indian tribes based on their per capita income, with tribes able to submit relevant information for consideration. The Secretary will determine payment proportions to Indian tribes based on per capita income, ensuring tribes receive no less than the amount specified for States. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments. The Secretary may modify requirements if it benefits the safety and best interests of children served by the tribes. The Secretary may modify requirements under this part if it benefits the safety and best interests of children served by Indian tribes. Participating Indian tribes in an intertribal consortium can submit a single plan under section 471. Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums can enter into cooperative agreements with States for fund administration or payment. Any cooperative agreement incorporating provisions of this section will be valid and enforceable. Cooperative agreements between Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums and States incorporating provisions of this section are valid and enforceable. The Secretary will promulgate regulations within a year of enactment in consultation with Indian tribes. Definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The amendments made by this section regarding the definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' take effect upon enactment of the Act, regardless of regulations being in place.
